text: English grammar lesson 25 topic articles
with languages countries and
nationalities this is a lesson in two
parts in part one will focus on learning
the guidelines is there a friend you
really admire I admire my friend you
girl she's from Japan although she's
Japanese she speaks English very well I
admire you go not only because she's so
good with languages but also because
she's a good person
I love having conversations with her
because she's funny and she's also a
very good listener I've asked you go to
join me in this lesson and help you
learn when we use articles with
countries languages and nationalities
listening task 1 pay attention to the
use of articles with languages
you go I'd love to tell you how much I
admire your English I think your English
is so very good thank you can you tell
me though I know Japanese it's your
native language you speak English
do you speak any other languages yes I
actually also speak a little bit of
Spanish that's right that's right that's
three languages
Wow languages need no article if used
alone for example you go speaks Japanese
she also knows Spanish we use a zero
article no article before Japanese and
Spanish this is the most common pattern
especially after verbs like speak no
understand however if you use the word
language then we use the definite
article as in the Japanese language is
very complex
listening tasks to pay attention to the
use of articles with countries
how did you come to know three languages
I learned my English when I went to an
international school growing up in Japan
I picked up Spanish when I studied
abroad in Spain for a year okay
[Music]
most countries need no article for
example you go is from Japan she studied
in Spain we use a zero article no
article before Japan and Spain however
some countries need a definite article
and I'll talk about myself for a moment
to give you a few examples
Jennifer lives in the u.s. she took a
trip to the Soviet Union in 1989 she
worked in the Bahamas after college
United States Soviet Union Bahamas these
are three examples of countries that
need a definite article the general
guideline is that kingdoms republics
unions and countries with names that are
plural like Bahamas require a definite
article
listening task 3 pay attention to the
use of articles with nationalities
your English though is so American you
study English in Japan but to my ears
it's very American so who are your
teachers my teachers when I was in
elementary school especially first
second and third grade were Americans
and I think that's where I definitely
picked up my American accent okay now
you said you spent a whole year in Spain
yes
did you study and live that in a
dormitory or where did you live no
actually I lived with a Spanish family
so you've spent time in three cultures
you've been in the United States so you
know the American culture you obviously
know the Japanese culture and you've had
some time in Spain you know Spanish
culture can you tell me some differences
among these cultures like what makes an
American different from a Spaniard or a
Spaniard different from someone from
Japan what's the difference between the
Japanese and the Spanish or the Spanish
and Americans the one easy difference
between a Japanese and Americans are
that the Japanese I think are a little
more reserved they tend to be a little
more private you really need to get to
know them before they start opening up
to you I think Americans and Spaniards
are similar and that they are very
friendly but just like the Japanese I
think you really do need to get to
a Spanish person better before they
really truly open up I feel that the
Americans are most open in terms of
being friendly to people you really can
strike a conversation in that elevator
and that would not happen in Japan right
[Music]
many nationalities have one form that is
both an adjective and a noun for example
Jennifer is an American she married a
Russian here American and Russian are
being used as nouns singular nouns one
I'm identifying myself as one American
I'm identifying my husband as one
Russian let's look at the second half of
this statement her husband learned that
an American wife wasn't exactly like a
Russian wife here the words American and
Russian are being used as adjectives
we're describing the noun wife so the
same form is being used both as an
adjective and as a noun a singular noun
you can look at the ending and see a
pattern American Russian a n is the
ending so this pattern will hold true
for other nationalities such as
Brazilian Canadian Australian however
you need to understand that some
nationalities don't have the same forms
for adjectives and nouns
let's compare people from the United
States to people from Japan so you
understand this point Jennifer is
American you go is Japanese American
Japanese are adjectives now let's look
at singular nouns she's an American I
can use the same form and simply use an
indefinite article to say one American
can I do this with Japanese
no it is not correct to say she's a
Japanese I have to use the adjective
plus another noun she is a Japanese
woman or simply she's Japanese let's
look at the plural nouns what are
Americans like again I took the same
form and I simply added a plural ending
s can I do this with Japanese no it is
incorrect to say what are Japanese is
like I could say what are the Japanese
like using the definite article here's a
tip with all nationalities you can
simply use the adjective plus the word
people what are American people like
what are Japanese people like let's talk
more about the pattern you just saw with
Japanese you saw the definite article
plus an adjective to refer to a whole
group in other words the before the
adjective form of a nationality can
refer to the whole population but this
pattern is limited to these endings YZ s
ish or CH examples include the Chinese
the Swiss the Irish the Dutch unlike
nationalities such as Americans
Canadians and Russians we cannot simply
add an S we can't say chineses swiss
--is Irish's and duchess the alternative
is to use the plus the adjective the
Chinese the Swiss the Irish the Dutch
let's talk about making generic
references that is referring to the
whole group and not one particular
person or people within the group with
nationalities that have a plural noun
form you can use a zero or definite
article to make a generic reference here
are two examples Russians love good
conversation
the Russians were the first to put a man
in space in both sentences I have the
same plural known Russians in the first
I used a zero article no article and in
the second I chose to use the definite
article the both sentences refer to
Russians as a whole group in the first
sentence I'm talking about a
characteristic that the whole group
shares in general all people of this
nationality love good conversation in
the second sentence I'm referring to the
whole population I'm talking about what
all the people of this country achieved
together I feel that pattern with the
definite article plus the plural noun is
very common especially in the context of
history such as the first to put a man
in space now let's talk about making
specific references you always need a
definite article to make a specific
reference for example the Americans did
well at the Winter Olympics in Vancouver
and brought home a number of gold medals
here I'm not talking about all Americans
the whole group of Americans but a
specific number of Americans the
athletes that participated in these
games finally let me call attention to
some special noun forms often among
nationalities ending in YZ s ich and CH
are special singular noun forms for
example people from Finland can be
referred to as the Finnish but one
person is a Finn people from France we
can call the French but one person is a
Frenchman people from Poland can be
referred to as the Polish but one person
is a pole people from Spain can be
referred to as the Spanish but one
person is a
spaniard and the people in sweden can be
called
the Swedish but one person is a Swede my
first piece of advice is to consult a
dictionary if you're not certain about
the noun form the second piece of advice
is you can never be wrong by simply
using the adjective or the adjective
plus a noun you can talk about a Finnish
person or simply say he or she is
finnish this is the end of part 1 before
you go on to part 2 please note that
additional practice is available at
English cafe.com
my username is Jennifer ESL follow the
direct link listed in the video
description
check out the exercise I have there and
then go on to part 2
